results.abstract: Theaters were shut but the ceremony is still happening? Yep! In a podcast, our awards experts catch you up.

results.title: When Co-Stars Compete at the Oscars, Who Wins?

results.title: Yuh-Jung Youn becomes the first Korean woman in Oscar history to win best supporting actress.
results.abstract: “How can I win over Glenn Close?” Youn said while accepting the award for her role in “Minari.” “Tonight, I have just a little bit luck, I think, maybe.”

results.title: Chloé Zhao becomes the first woman of color to win best director.

results.title: Mia Neal and Jamika Wilson are the first Black women to win for hair and makeup.
results.abstract: They are also the first ever to be nominated in the category since it was introduced in 1981.

results.title: Behind ‘Strange Fruit,’ Billie Holiday’s Anti-Lynching Anthem
results.abstract: It helped make Holiday a star, but it was written by Abel Meeropol, a teacher in the Bronx. An Oscar nomination and a year of protests against racism have kept it in the conversation.
des_facet: The United States vs Billie Holiday (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Billie Holiday at a recording session in 1939. The film “The United States vs. Billie Holiday” chronicles the government’s efforts to suppress the song “Strange Fruit.”

results.title: Volatile and Vengeful: How Scott Rudin Wielded Power in Show Business
results.abstract: For decades, the producer has cultivated and castigated people at all levels of entertainment. Now his past is catching up with him.
results.byline: By Michael Paulson and Cara Buckley

results.title: Oscars: The Stars We’ve Lost
results.abstract: With the Oscars approaching, we’re remembering big stars who died in the past year.
results.byline: By Erica Ackerberg and Amy Padnani

results.title: How ‘Rocks’ Made Stars of Its Schoolgirl Cast
results.abstract: By casting first-time actors, the film tells a story rarely seen onscreen: what growing up is like for British women of color.

multimedia.caption: Clockwise from top: Ruby Stokes, Kosar Ali, Bukky Bakray, Anastasia Dymitrow, Tawheda Begum and Afi Okaidja. The casting team for “Rocks” saw 1,300 girls to find actors to play the film’s East London teenagers.

Clockwise from top: Ruby Stokes, Kosar Ali, Bukky Bakray, Anastasia Dymitrow, Tawheda Begum and Afi Okaidja. The casting team for “Rocks” saw 1,300 girls to find actors to play the film’s East London teenagers.

Clockwise from top: Ruby Stokes, Kosar Ali, Bukky Bakray, Anastasia Dymitrow, Tawheda Begum and Afi Okaidja. The casting team for “Rocks” saw 1,300 girls to find actors to play the film’s East London teenagers.

Clockwise from top: Ruby Stokes, Kosar Ali, Bukky Bakray, Anastasia Dymitrow, Tawheda Begum and Afi Okaidja. The casting team for “Rocks” saw 1,300 girls to find actors to play the film’s East London teenagers.

Clockwise from top: Ruby Stokes, Kosar Ali, Bukky Bakray, Anastasia Dymitrow, Tawheda Begum and Afi Okaidja. The casting team for “Rocks” saw 1,300 girls to find actors to play the film’s East London teenagers.

results.title: ‘Tu Me Manques’ Review: Traces of a Lost Love
